title: Army Corps of Engineers shares progress on Folly Beach renourishment
message:
FOLLY BEACH, S.C. (WCSC) - The U.S. Army Corps of Engineers is showing progress on a multi-million-dollar effort to preserve Lowcountry beaches.
The Folly Beach renourishment project, designed to combat the effects of Hurricane Ian, is reaching an upcoming, six-month construction milestone.
“The beach was so eroded at the time of Hurricane Ian, in that December storm, because the project had not done its job.
The work will also go toward preserving the future of the shoreline during the upcoming peak hurricane season.
The map shows a completed stretch of the renourishment project from the Folly Beach County Park to the pier.
event_breakdown:
The natural-disaster events mentioned in the text are:

* Hurricane Ian - A hurricane that caused erosion to the shoreline of the Folly Beach renourishment project area.
* Folly Beach renourishment project - A multi-million-dollar effort by the U.S. Army Corps of Engineers to preserve Lowcountry beaches and combat the effects of Hurricane Ian.
* Construction milestone - The upcoming six-month construction milestone of the Folly Beach renourishment project, showing progress on preserving the shoreline.
* Peak hurricane season - The upcoming peak hurricane season that the beach renourishment project will also work to protectfrom storm damage.

title: Officials hold hurricane preparedness roundtable in Doral ahead of start of hurricane season - WSVN 7News | Miami News , Weather , Sports
message:
DORAL, FLA. (WSVN) - As hurricane season approaches, talks are already underway on how to make Florida storm ready.
Florida Division of Emergency Management held a roundtable discussion with officials on Monday in Doral at the Miami-Dade Emergency Operations Center.
Topic discussions included how to prepare for what could be an above-normal season, possibly the highest on record.
Hurricanes in Florida in 2023 caused billions of dollars in damages and killed multiple people.
The 2024 Atlantic Hurricane Season begins on June 1.
event_breakdown:
1. Florida Division of Emergency Management hosted a roundtable discussion with officials on Monday in Doral at the Miami-Dade Emergency Operations Center to discuss how to make Florida storm ready ahead of hurricane season.
2. According to officials, the season is expected to be above-normal, and possibly the highest on record.
3. There have been several hurricanes in Florida in previous years that caused billions of dollars in damages and killed multiple people.
4. The 2024 Atlantic Hurricane Season begins on June 1.

In light of this information, there have been several disasters related to hurricanes in Florida in the past, and there is concern for the upcoming hurricane season. These were some of the topics discussed in the roundtable discussion.

title: B . C . mayor says drones endangering wildfire helicopter pilots , pleads for patience | iNFOnews
message:
mayor says drones endangering wildfire helicopter pilots, pleads for patienceA helicopter lands with crews returning from fighting wildfires near Fort McMurray, Alta., Thursday, May 16, 2024.
says drones are endangering helicopters being used to fight wildfires near Fort Nelson, which was ordered evacuated earlier this month.
THE CANADIAN PRESS/Jeff McIntoshOriginal Publication Date May 20, 2024 - 4:31 PMFORT NELSON, B.C.
- The mayor of the Northern Rockies Regional Municipality in British Columbia says drones are endangering helicopters being used to fight wildfires near Fort Nelson, which was ordered evacuated earlier this month.
The B-C Wildfire Service said Monday that favourable weather in the next few day in the province's northeast will help crews make progress, but the drought situation means conditions are still unseasonably dry.
event_breakdown:
form
The natural-disasters events mentioned in the text are:

1. Wildfires near Fort McMurray, Alta.
2. Wildfires near Fort Nelson, B.C., which was ordered evacuated earlier this month.

title: Seismic storm hits Italy Campi Flegrei super volcano with strongest earthquake in 40 years
message:
A 4.4 magnitude earthquake struck Italy’s Campi Flegrei super volcano Monday evening, causing mild damage in the town of Pozzuoli, the epicenter, and as far away as the city of Naples, some 20 kilometers (12 miles) away, according to Italy’s National Institute of Geophysics and Volcanology (INGV).
The 4.4 earthquake at a depth of 3 kilometers is the strongest earthquake to hit the highly seismic area in the past 40 years, according to INGV data.
The quake is part of an ongoing “seismic storm” that has seen more than a dozen events over 2.0 magnitude in the past 48 hours.
The INGV recorded 1,252 earthquakes in the Campi Flegrei area in the month of April 2024, most with a magnitude less than 1.0.
More than 500,000 people live in the red zone directly adjacent to the Campi Flegrei, according to the Italian Civil Protection agency, which has been working this year to update evacuation plans in the event of a major disaster.
event_breakdown:
Here is the list of natural-disasters events mentioned in this text:

* A 4.4 magnitude earthquake struck Italy’s Campi Flegrei super volcano with an epicenter near the town of Pozzuoli on Monday evening. The quake was the strongest to hit the area in the past 40 years.
* The earthquake is part of an ongoing “seismic storm” that has seen more than a dozen events over 2.0 magnitude in the past 48 hours.
* The total number of earthquakes recorded in the area reached 1,252 in the month of April 2o24, most of them with a magnitude less than 1.0.

title: Storms damage homes in Oklahoma ,  Kansas ,  but most power restored in Houston
message:
WICHITA, Kan. — Fast-moving storms with strong winds, large hail and apparent tornadoes swept Oklahoma and Kansas, blowing roofs off homes and blocking roads with toppled trees and downed power lines.
In central Kansas, a 100 mph wind gust was reported at the airport in Salina, the National Weather Service said.
The weather service said it received 13 tornado reports Sunday from Oklahoma, Kansas and Colorado.
Parts of Nebraska, Iowa and Minnesota could also see some flooding with heavy rain swelling rivers and creeks, the weather service said.
Thursday’s storms left at least seven dead and brought much of Houston to a standstill.
event_breakdown:
The events listed in the text are as follows:

1. Fast-moving storms with strong winds, large hail and apparent tornadoes swept Oklahoma and Kansas, blowing roofs off homes and blocking roads with toppled trees and downed power lines.

2. In central Kansas, a 100 mph wind gust was reported at the airport in Salina, the National Weather Service said.

3. The weather service said it received 13 tornado reports from Oklahoma, Kansas and Colorado.

4. Parts of Nebraska, Iowa and Minnesota could also see some flooding with heavy rain swelling rivers and creeks, the weather service said.

5. Thursday’s storms left at least seven dead and brought much of Houston to a standstill.

Please note that these events are related to one another and are all part of the natural-disasters events mentioned in the text.

title: New study reveals devastating impact single hurricane could have on forested regions :  We have to adequately account for the risks
message:
Just one hurricane could leave devastating impacts on forests in a single region of the United States and their ability to lower air pollutants, a study has found.
Across the country, forests have been found to help mitigate air pollution by storing and sequestering carbon in tree tissue.
The authors claimed a single hurricane could release 10 or more years' worth of sequestered carbon.
Extreme weather events like hurricanes have always occurred across the country.
However, impacts of human-induced climate change can drastically enhance these weather events, making them more severe or frequent.
event_breakdown:
1. Spawning hurricanes
2. Environmental impacts of hurricanes on forests
3. Release of sequestered carbon by forests
4. Hurricane-induced air pollution

Fast-moving storms with strong winds, large hail and apparent tornadoes swept Oklahoma and Kansas, blowing roofs off homes and blocking roads with toppled trees and downed power lines.
In central Kansas, a 100 mph wind gust was reported at the airport in Salina, the National Weather Service said.
The weather service said it received 13 tornado reports Sunday from Oklahoma, Kansas and Colorado.
The National Weather Service warned of an enhanced risk of severe storms late Monday night into early Tuesday in parts of Colorado, Kansas and Nebraska.
Parts of Nebraska, Iowa and Minnesota could also see some flooding with heavy rain swelling rivers and creeks, the weather service said.

title: Fla . stockpiling millions of meals , gallons of water ahead of hurricane season
message:
That's the warning from some of the nation's top meteorologists as the official start of the Atlantic hurricane season nears.
Its latest numbers show officials have 1.5 million gallons of water, with another 1 million gallons on the way.
The Florida Division of Emergency Management is stockpiling 1.5 million gallons of drinking water ahead of the 2024 Atlantic hurricane season.
Later this week, the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration will update its predictions on the upcoming Atlantic hurricane season.
The Atlantic hurricane season runs from June to November.
event_breakdown: Atlantic Hurricane Season

title: Homes evacuated amid storm warnings
message:
Supplied: Celeste DonovanResidents in a community near Lake Rotorua are being asked to evacuate their homes as a storm that flooded dozens of houses in Auckland heads south.
The Bay of Plenty Regional Council has activated its Flood Room emergency response because of the Ngongotahā river levels rising.
Tolaga Bay School principal Nori Parata says the school is sending home students on the Tokomaru Bay, Anaura Bay and Tauwhareparae buses, so they can get home safe before road conditions worsen.
and there is now a severe thunderstorm watch in place for Waikato, Bay of Plenty, Rotorua, Taupō and Gisborne.
Hawke's Bay is forecast to receive up to 200mm of rain, mostly south of SH5.
event_breakdown:
Here's the list of natural-disaster events in the text:
1. Flooding in Auckland, New Zealand. Dozens of houses were affected.
2. Flooding near Lake Rotorua. Residents were asked to evacuate.
3. Rising river levels at Ngongotahā. The Bay of Plenty Regional Council activated its Flood Room emergency response.
4. Storm conditions that could potentially worsen road conditions. Tolaga Bay School sent home students who live in affected areas to ensure they got home safe.
5. A severe thunderstorm watch for Waikato, Bay of Plenty, Rotorua, Taupō and Gisborne.
6. Heavy rainfall of up to 200mm forecast for Hawke's Bay, mostly south of State Highway 5.

title: Gulf Shores Hurricane Preparedness Expo set for June 6 2024
message:
The City of Gulf Shores will host its annual Hurricane Preparedness Expo on Thursday, June 6, from 10 a.m. to 2 p.m. at the Erie H. Meyer Civic Center.
This free event offers the public an opportunity to educate themselves on hurricane preparedness and the many products and services available before, during, and after a storm.
According to Gulf Shores Emergency Management Coordinator Brandan Franklin, the event will feature federal, state, and local agencies, and several local businesses that specialize in storm products and services.
Chief Meteorologist Ed Bloodsworth from WKRG’s News 5 Alert Team will be onsite at the event and will give a special presentation at 11:30 a.m.Additionally, the City of Gulf Shores will have several departments on hand to answer questions.
If you are a resident of Gulf Shores and do not have an up-to-date (2023-2024) Hurricane decal, this is a great time to obtain one.
event_breakdown: The Hurricane Preparedness Expo in Gulf Shores, AL is an annual public event that offers residents an opportunity to learn about hurricane preparedness and gain information on resources available during the disaster. Several federal agencies, state organizations, and local vendors will be in attendance to provide products and answer questions. Local forecaster Ed Bloodsworth will also be present for a presentation on getting prepared for the upcoming season.

message:
(WOWT) - Both Monday & Tuesday are 6 First Alert Weather Days as we continue to monitor the potential for severe storms.
Stay weather aware through Tuesday afternoon as multiple rounds of strong to severe storms are possible.
TuesdayMonday, 11:50PM - Severe Thunderstorm Watch runs until 7AM Tuesday due to overnight storm threat and a more organized early morning risk for high wind.
Severe T-Storm Watch (wowt)The greatest storm potential will likely hold off until after 8pm tonight and last into the overnight.
Overnight storm threat (wowt)Monday Threats (WOWT)On top of the severe weather threat we’ll also see a concern for flooding near and N of I-80 where overnight storms could lead to frequent downpours and cumulative rain totals of over 3″ for some.

title: Status of Wildfire That Threatened Fort McMurray Changed to  Being Held
message:
A wildfire that forced thousands of people to evacuate several Fort McMurray neighbourhoods last week is no longer classified as out-of-control.
Alberta Wildfire says the blaze, which is still burning south of the city and is close to 2,000 square kilometres in size, was re-classified to “being held” as of May 19.
In announcing the change on social media, Alberta Wildfire says recent rain allowed firefighters and heavy equipment operators to make excellent progress on containing the fire.
An evacuation alert for the entire city of Fort McMurray , which told residents they should be ready to leave at short notice, was lifted at the same time.
Alberta Wildfire says over 40 millimetres of rain has fallen on the fire since May 16.
location: The main location where the main event takes place is Fort McMurray, Alberta.
event_breakdown:
Wildfire (Fort McMurray) (2022) (so far)
Fort McMurray siren (eviction alert)

title: Flagstaff community helping donate labor , supplies after flash floods
message:
FLAGSTAFF, AZ — The Flagstaff community is helping donate labor and supplies to build a wall around a home that has seen repeated flash floods during monsoon season.
Elden Estates neighborhood that was hit by multiple flash floods in the summer of 2021 because of heavy rains that fell on the burn scars from the Museum Fire.
ABC15 first met Anissa in August of 2021 while working on a story about her concerns about the repeated floods.
Photos and videos of those flash floods have been hard for Anissa.
“You are not allowed to build a flood wall, not allowed to do any flood mitigation,” said Meagan Elliott, with Showtime Dirt Works.
event_breakdown:
.
- Repeated flash floods during monsoon season in Elden Estates neighborhood, Flagstaff, Arizona, USA.
- Concerns about the repeated floods shared by Anissa in August 2021 due to heavy rains that fell on the burn scars from the Museum Fire.
